Crossing the Potomac. Past the Lincoln Memorial. While--
Felt enters on Asst. to the President JOHN EHRLICHMAN, 45 staring out his window at the bedlam; and Special Counsel JOHN DEAN, 33 and boyish. And Attorney General JOHN MITCH 59.

Gentlemen. Have a seat, Felt. (as Felt sits--) CLOSE IN in on Felt’s eyes. Which have a rare and trained hyper-awareness. Capturing the smallest details like a camera: a patch of perspiration on Ehrlichman’s forehead; smudge on Dean’s shoe.
Goddamn Russian Revolution out there. Why aren’t we arresting anybody?
Because that-- (out there) Isn’t a crime. (which turns him)
We know why you’re here, Felt. But before all that. The President needs your advice. Dean moves to the side for a better angle.
Hoover’s run the FBI, what, Fifty. forty years?
Fifty goddamn years! You know Johnson and Kennedy wanted to fire him, don’t you? But they didn’t have the balls. (MORE )
(and he looks and waits, but--) Felt is saying nothing. And after an uncomfortable pause-
Did you know the President wanted to be an FBI G-Man, just like you? Hoover wrote him personally what a damn fine candidate he was, but with budget cuts the FBI couldn't afford him.
How’s that for a lesson in fate? Now he’s President of the United States. Pause.
If the President were going to ask Mr. Hoover to step aside, how would you suggest he do it? And Felt goes still, as a dog will at a sign of danger.
We know you to be a friend to this administration. And we like to see our friends get what they deserve--
You’re next in line.
There is no line.
The President is asking. Pause. A hesitation. Exasperation.
Mr. Hoover would want to keep his bullet-proof car. And his secretary. I’d offer him that.
You're a real politician, Felt.
I’m a law man.  Polite smiles. Maybe a chuckle.

As the President likes to say, there are two kinds of people in politics - winners and losers. I knew a loser once and he was a queer. (intoning) Gentlemen, Mark Felt is no loser! (as Felt stays stoic, patient) So okay, Felt, go ahead, fire away. Felt’s errand--
As you know Mr. Hoover has heard rumors of the presence of homosexuals at the highest levels of the White House.
Who’s the fag supposed to be?
Is he here in this room? You want to polygraph us? (and they laugh) Except Dean. The lawyer. Unamused.
Does the FBI really need to spend resources on this? (laughter dies) Do we?
I can take it from here.
Then thanks for popping by. (and as the show is over, and they start to focus on other things--)
If I may-- (they’re annoyed) There is one thing Mr. Hoover knows has been on all your minds. (and just like that he has their attention again) (MORE )

Whenever the FBI hears a piece of gossip, or information, such as: 'I saw so-and-so out with another woman not his wife. Or a man not his wife'- (and start a slow push in) We’re supposed to write everything down. And we do. Write it all down. In memos. (gives that some air) These memos come to me and I decide what information Mr. Hoover needs to know, and send that up to Mr. Hoover. And Mr. Hoover puts it all away. In his private files. (--)

To be kept safe. Out of the hands of people without discretion. People who could do harm. Should that information be leaked, for instance. And put before the court of public opinion. TIGHT on Felt’s face until it fills the screen. To these this face is now the still center of the universe.

And then sometimes Mr. Hoover will go, for instance, to the President's closest aides, and say - 'Mr. Ehrlichman, I want you to know that we received that report about you and that other woman, and I want to tell you that there is absolutely no reason for us to take any further action. Precise numbers. Mr. Miller. The formality surprises us. Not them. Another photo. Four charred corpses.

He’s dead.

Put everything into motion. No mistakes, gentlemen. Not one. (Bates crosses and leaves, then Miller) And Felt and Carol are left alone. Holding a long look. Carol’s face says, “You’re the new director.”

She worships you. You are her moon and stars. (--)

There’s a price to pay for what we do, Mr. Miller. There’s a price to pay for what we become. We all pay it, one way or another. (and turns, and leaves Miller standing there, and cut to--) INT. FELT’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 89 Felt shuts the door, sits. Takes a breath. We PAN AROUND see he’s contemplating that photo of Joan.
Mrs. Felt on the phone.

Take a message. (and--) Takes a stack of 50 blank envelopes out of his briefcase. Taps them to align edges. Pulls out his wallet, and out o that a folded piece of paper. PUSH IN CLOSE and we SEE a list of addresses written in Felt’s impeccable calligraphy-like script. With painstaking precision, Felt starts addressing envelo Each to a different address, but every one in California. INT. FELT’S HOME - LATER THAT NIGHT 90
Indian summer. The air thick. Felt enters in his suit, ha

Audrey? Nothing. Goes deeper into the house. We pick up the SOUND ice tumbling in a glass. Felt is stopped in the den, by t sight of her outside, in the dark, pool lights off. Knows what that means. Braces himself, and And he heads out to-  91 61. EXT. BACK YARD - FELT’S HOME 91 Audrey's smoking and drinking on a chaise poolside, contemplating the night. Felt approaches. She hands the cigarette up. Felt takes a drag, hands it back. He sips a her drink. Bottle of gin by her foot.

Maybe she’s dead. Maybe she just gave up, didn’t think anyone cared. Or christ-- (and waves at the woods) Maybe she never left. Maybe she’s right out there, watching us. To see what a man like you does when your daughter just vanishes one night for no good reason.
Joan had a reason for everything.
Oh, [here we go again] it was my fault?
You hated her.
Mothers don’t hate their daughters! It’s just not always easy being one!
She was beautiful and smart. You dressed her up like a doll. Until she got old enough to look just like you. You were jealous. And you hated her for it--
Mark. Don’t-- You kept telling her to get out. Until one day she listened to you.
I'm begging you listen to me. But she did-- I had no mother-
No. Listen to me! (and she takes his hands) My mother was 47 when she had me. And my father just left. (MORE )

There weren’t many ways for a woman to support herself, to survive-- (and Felt slows; this is new; hearing this for the first time--) --So yes, she did, she gave me up. To foster homes. She didn’t want to lose her daughter completely. But then the orphanage. And then she just stopped coming back-- (and stops herself; this biblical realization) Felt lowering to a chair, lights a cigarette. Listening. Always collecting clues to his wife. As she goes on--

And when I was eleven, I was placed in that home, and I loved it. They told me to call them mom and dad. But they told me to my face that they'd keep me only until I went into puberty. As soon as I had my first period I was out, because they didn’t want to deal with all that. All that womanhood, and boys. So when I got my first period I didn’t want to leave. I hid the rags. And I had to use rags, to wash myself, after everyone went to bed so they wouldn’t know. And then they did find out. And then I was just gone. (--)
And then I made it on my own. (--)
Until you. My white knight. You’re everything to me. The homes we made were the only homes I ever had. When you walk into a room you're the only thing I see.
You are both mine. And now tries to embrace her. Mine. The phone starts ring inside the house. And just as quickly the moment is lost-
Don’t (leave)-- I need to get that.  63. And he watches her cross to the kitchen and then to the phone. Watching her through the window pick up the phone. Chipper. Like nothing has happened.

(into phone) Hello? ... Oh, hi, Margaret ... No I never made it, I was swamped with house work... (and now--) Felt turns to the pool. Stands there a beat. Strips off h shirt. His pants. Then slips into the water. Until he’s gone beneath a rash bubbles. And we stay with-- FELT’S POV. Looking from the bottom up at a rectangle of Audrey in view, wavy through the interference of water. Felt about to burst. But can’t rise. Hungry for the quiet dark isolation. Desperate for the safety of the coming de Until a beat before drowning we rise with him. And he EXPLODES to the surface, GASPING FOR BREATH. And lifts himself out of the pool. Dripping and shivering Listening to Audrey gossip, we BEGIN TO HEAR in PRE-LAP:
(PRE-LAP)
Three-hundred thirty-three Agents from fifty-one field offices around the country developed one-thousand eight-hundred and ninety-seven leads... (and we cut to--)

head_text.subj: THE ATTORNEY GENERAL'S TV NEWS CONFERENCE

text: ...one-thousand five-hundred and fifty-one interviews, spending fourteen-thousand ninety-eight man hours. Watergate was the most intensive, objective and thorough investigation in the history of the U.S. Attorney’s office and the FBI. (MORE )
The Justice Department has now completed its criminal investigation without implicating any present officials of either the White House or the Committee to Re- elect the President.
Completed?? What the hell? (PULL BACK TO REVEAL--)
Lano and Kunkel watching the TV. Ten Agents crowd the doo
Somebody get me Felt on the phone. As the news CUTS TO a SIMULTANEOUS JOHN DEAN NEWS CONFERE
Hold on-- wait a second.

Ties to the White House? Two former White House people, low level, indicted, one consultant and one member of the Domestic Council staff. That's not very much of a tie. (then) I understand the FBI’s Watergate investigation is in a state of repose and unlikely to be reopened. (and back to--)
Anybody tell us this thing was over?!
Meanwhile, just forty-two days before election day, President Nixon’s approval ratings continue to rocket-- Kunkel MUTES the TV.
Where the hell’s Felt? Or Bates. Goddammit get Felt on the phone!  93 65.
I can’t.
Why the hell not?

Because he’s right there. They turn to the shitty little TV. And so do we: Where Felt is standing like a stone lion on one side of t Attorney General, Gray on the other. Matching bookends of authority. Playing his role. Then cut to-- INT. GRAY’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 93 Felt enters. Disturbed by what he’s just done.
How’s home, Mark?
Why do you ask?
That daughter of yours? Jill?
Joan.

I hear she’s terrific. Fulbright scholar! First girl in the country! Chip off the old block. (after a heavy silence) Have a seat. (Felt stays standing, which Gray notes - “okay” - but just--) I want you to be the first to hear my statement to the press. (reading) ‘No pressure has been put on me or any of my special agents in the FBI’s investigation, and that it strains’ -- I thought I would just nip this in the bud -- ‘it strains credulity that President Nixon could have done a con job on the whole American people.’ (looks up) What do you think?  94 66.
It’s just fine.
Our job is done. Tie up the loose ends. Then shut it all down. (and after a beat--)
(simply) Okay.
The daily meeting. All 27 Agents. Felt and Bates against the back wall. All acutely aware o and not particularly happy with - their presence.

(grim) The Democrats issued a statement this morning. (reading) “The FBI's Watergate investigation is a whitewash--” PUSH IN ON FELT while hearing the rest of this. He redden Jaw clenches. Hands clench into fists...

--"What is involved here is not only the political life of this nation, but the very morality of our leaders at a time when the United States desperately needs to revitalize its moral standards--” (it’s killing Felt, like nothing else could kill Felt) That’s it. Despondent silence. Nothing left to say. Then--

Well, gentlemen, here’s what we know. We know what we’ve heard out of the Department of Justice the last two days is bullshit. (he has their attention) We know the men who broke into the Watergate are not the end of this thing but the beginning. (MORE )

We know this is the latest link in a chain of illegal covert intelligence operations by the President's re-election campaign. We know we are facing obstruction from multiple fronts. From the White House. From the Central Intelligence Agency. From the Attorney General of the United States. Who is our boss. (--)

It is not our job to speculate on the involvement of the President. It is our job to follow the bread crumbs. But those bread crumbs appear to be taking us on a tour of the West Wing of the White House, and in the general direction of the Oval Office. We also know we’ve been ordered to shut down our pursuit of all this as of today. And we know that except for the thirty men in this room no one in the entire country knows any of this, and may never know any of this-- Unless we tell them. (and now) No one can stop the driving force of an FBI investigation. Not even the FBI. The agents are stunned. Energized. Felt outwardly calm, b as we MOVE IN TIGHTER, we see he is vibrating with rage.
So what else? (and then we find him--)

Felt and Bates walking briskly back to FBI HQ. INT. FELT’/S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 96 CAROL sorting Felt’s mail. Comes on one of the envelopes had mailed. It’s stamped ‘Return to sender’. She adds it stack of five just like that. She walks the envelopes to Felt.  97 98 99 68. Felt stares at the “return to senders”. He pulls out the of addresses, neatly checks off the ones that have come b It's almost half of them now. He unlocks a bottom drawer and lifts out a neat stack of twenty of the same envelopes. Looks up. Carol has not moved. She is standing in the middle of the room looking at him. Connecting and speaking with her eye And, finally, nod. Of knowing. And support.

Felt sits at his easel. Autumn leaves whirlpooling around him. His paint brush an inch away from the surface, froze mid-air. His EYES FIXED we think on the woods, contemplat maybe the lean of a tree. Now cut to--

Through a wall of window glass letting out onto the stree we see Audrey in private class with a YOUNG INSTRUCTOR. H sexy, virile. She is heavily made up. We stay wide, long. They salsa excellently across the frame. Sultry. Close. N

FELT AT HIS EASEL. PAN AROUND and SEE the canvas is perfe white. And his eyes fixed not on a tree but an idea. And to-- AUDREY and instructor, gyrating, spinning. Faster like a picking up speed. Head tipped. Drunk. In both ways. Then back to and-- PUSH IN CLOSE ON THE TIP OF FELT’S BRUSH. A bead of paint drops, and we follow its fall ... and as it SPLASHES on Felt’s knee-- EXT./INT. LAUNDROMAT/FELT’S CAR - NIGHT 99

Felt’s Buick pulls up. Stops at a phone booth. Rain drums hard against the windows. Felt’s not getting out. He’s sitting there watching the rain. On the seat beside him, and FBI memo stamped “Confidentia PUSH IN on the memo. TIGHT ON: “Shipley ...Segretti. Whit House ...political espionage...sabotage... Now up to--

Felt. He’s thinking about his life and its consequences.  69. This is very much like that moment in the life of a man w has not yet cheated on his wife, but who is staring at a motel room door, on the other side of which lies a woman whom there will be no debate. Once he goes through that d life as he knows it will never be the same. Felt gets out of the car. Steps into the booth. Dimes. Di
(picking up--) Who's this?
I'm going to give you the name of a man who was asked to go to work for the Nixon administration in an unusual way.
What are you talking about?
I'm talking about political sabotage, crimes conceived in the White House, and run out of the White House. (pause) It’s all linked.
To what?

Watergate. (now a long quiet, then--) There is only one way to understand what Watergate really means, and this is it. (then) The name is Alex Shipley. Shipley. He lives in Nashville. The man who approached him was a lawyer out of L.A. named Donald Segretti. Segretti. S-E-G-R-E-T-T-I. (then) Shipley can tell you everything you need to know.
Will Shipley talk?
I guess you’re going to have to find that out. (MORE )
(then) One more thing. This comes from confidential FBI files. The Department of Justice has it. The White House has it. And now you have it.
Why do you have it?
You'll have to find that out, too. (--)
But first I want you to give it to somebody for me.
Who am I supposed to be?

You’re a government lawyer, aren’t you? Just tell them that. (and we fall back outside, past the glass) And watch Felt continue talking for a moment. Then he han up, and we smash cut to-- 100 INT. /EXT. FELT’S BUICK (MOVING) /STREETS - NIGHT 100 Felt slows up to and stops outside the dance studio. He watches the Young Instructor work a class of adults. His hands liberally on the hips of someone else’s wife. 101 INT. FELT’/S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 101 Felt sphinx-like at his desk with an expression of bored hostility. Bates and Kunkel monitoring against the wall. PAN to the man lowering himself in the chair across from Felt: 27, tweed jacket, earnest, nervous: BOB WOODWARD.
(flustered) Mr. Felt--
A pleasure to meet you.  71.
(confused, a little panicked) I didn’t have much time to prepare.

The FBI likes to extend courtesy to the press whenever it can, and Mr. Felt had a sudden opening. So, the usual rules. Mr. Felt will only confirm or deny. Nothing on the record or on background. Woodward looks to Felt. Felt is imperious and blank. Felt nods.
(making it up) Okay, so, regarding the break-in at the Watergate. We have Hunt standing outside the hotel that night.
I’1l confirm.
And we have two ex-CIA and two ex- FBI agents involved. Woodward dutifully makes a note.
And this check deposited in the account of one of the burglars. (Woodward and Felt hold a look) It was a CIA account, correct?
That is true. But I won’t confirm.
You just said it was true.
That doesn’t mean we want people to know that it’s true. So I won't confirm it.
I need more detail.
Get it somewhere else.  72. Pause. Woodward looks again to Felt for a sign. Nothing.
(surprised) That’s it? That’s what you want? You know how many people get to sit in that seat? Woodward takes a breath, throws what he guesses is the pa he was brought here to throw.

Just one more thing, I guess. Someone identifying himself as a ‘government lawyer’ called my colleague at the Post, Carl Bernstein, two nights ago. He gave us a name. (reading from notes) Alex Shipley. Bates and Kunkel shoot each other an amazed look. Felt’s simply doesn’t move.
Where’d you get that?
He’s the Assistant Attorney General of Tennessee.
We know who he is.
But is Shipley an FBI target?
No comment! We're not going to comment on that.
I’m not going to comment on that.
Shipley told my colleague--
You already spoke to Shipley?!  73.

Shipley was recruited - they tried to recruit him - to perform political espionage on behalf of the Nixon administration. He gave us the name of the recruiter. (from notes) Donald C. Segretti. Felt: nothing.
No comment!
Segretti we know is a former Treasury Department lawyer--
No comment!
No comment. STOP. Silence. Woodward looks up, bemused. Knows now why brought him here--
But I haven’t asked anything yet.
CAROL SHOVING WOODWARD OUT THE DOOR, then back to-- Felt, Bates and Kunkel.
Jesus christ who the hell’s talking to these guys?
‘Government lawyer’ could be ten thousand people in this town. They're semi-hysterical. Felt calm as shit.
Get Mr. Lano over to the Post. Find out where they’re getting their information.
Gladly.
And I want all our offices swept for bugs. Today.
Who would be crazy enough to bug the FBI? (Felt and Bates look at each other)
Whoever thinks they need to know what we know.
Phone rings.
(picking up) Hello?
(another extension) I have it. (she keeps listening; a silence, then--) Please hang up. She won't let go. Then she does. And goes to the sink. Felt enters.
Are you having an affair, Mark? (--)
Because I’m starting to wish you were.
Are you? (but didn’t mean to say it, and before she can answer) They’ve unplugged the system, and the FBI system is beautiful. We all knew where we fit in. (--)
We do our jobs and the machine gets it right. (--)
There are no heroes. Not now. Not anymore.  103 75. Felt exits, crosses to the driveway to his car in the carport. He gets in, and he backs out, and then we cut to
Felt in the phone booth.
Summoning me to the FBI like that--
(into phone) It wasn’t about you. Our conversations have to be protected. (then) Where did you get Shipley?
The source won’t give his name.
Shipley’s good information. You're on it now ... But we can’t do this by phone any more. This is more dangerous than you realize.
How dangerous?
When we meet you’1ll have to observe strict rules of counter- surveillance. How do you leave your apartment?
Front door.

(into phone) Take the alley. Don’t drive your own car. Take a taxi but switch taxies mid-way. Take the time you need. One hour, two hours. I won’t care if you're late, but if you’re being followed do not come near me. (he looks at his watch) 2 a.m. (and hangs up)  104 105 76.

A MAN STANDING SUBMERGED IN SHADOW. We’re in a parking garage. The man is smoking. It’s only when the cherry sur that we see it’s Felt. Woodward approaches. They stand there in silence. Both anxious, but for differ reasons. Then:
The story isn’t moving. Everyone stopped listening to you.
We're lost in detail.
That’s their plan. They want everyone confused. Confusion is control. A pause. Woodward is lost.
This is hard.
Of course it’s hard. (--)
You talk now.
We found Segretti.
Segretti’s important but don’t fall in love with him. He connects the pieces, but it runs all over the map. (--)
Everything was part of it. It’s a monster. (then) The truth could ruin the administration, and I mean ruin. (Woodward just looks at him, then--)  77.
How high. Does it go? And Felt a sudden recoil of shame, regret--
I have to do this my way! (flash of anger) There’s no going back now! A MATCH FLARES. Now we really see why Felt’s stretching t out. He’s nervous. Afraid. He seems thinner. Worn.
You still don’t understand what I’m giving you. (--)

Watergate is just a little corner of a massive conspiracy. Campaign spying and sabotage. Everyone and everything - and I mean everyone - is involved. (Woodward scribbling) The FBI did its job. It’s all in the files. If you put out the right story the public will scream. The Attorney General will have to let me keep going.
When you do, what are you going to find? They look at each other, thinking.
This is dangerous stuff you’re playing with. Especially if it’s known before November 7th.
(realizing) Election day.  78.
The White House is behind everything. But if they get past the election, they’re home free. The President is safe. And now he realizes.

The President. That’s how high. Felt turns away. We think for good. Then stops. Leaning against a car. Bends his knees, slowly lowers. Until he’s sitting on the cold cement. Tired. At the end of somethin Woodward sits on the garage floor opposite him, cross-leg

My editors know. That I’m talking to somebody. (Felt looks up sharply) But not who. They don’t ask. [Like they’re afraid to know. ] (Felt looks furious) I'm not going to tell anyone who you are. That’s the deal, I understand. (--)
But they know it’s someone deep inside. Someone who can see everything. No one understands how one person knows so much.
No one can possibly know how much I know. He means about everything, of course. Not just this. A pa then--
With all this mystery, there’s a nickname for you at the paper. (--)
‘Deep Throat’. Felt stares at him. As if not metabolizing. As if not hav heard. Then his look forms a shape: distaste, disgust.
They didn’t know what else to call you.
They shouldn’t have to call me anything. (--)
Take out your notebook. There’s more. (and now we cut to--)
Audrey standing barefoot on the lawn, the Washington Post her hands. She’s scanning the front page.
PUSH IN CLOSE ON THE PAPER - HEADLINE: “FBI Finds Nixon A Sabotaged Democrats”.
(reading) “FBI agents have established that the Watergate bugging incident stemmed from a massive campaign of political spying and sabotage conducted on behalf of President Nixon's re-election...”
Felt stirs his Folger’s at the kitchen sink. Reading to h from the table.

“,..and directed by officials of the White House and the Committee for the Re-election of the President. Nixon knows that something is being done. It’s a typical deal, Segretti said. It’s don’ t-ask-and-I-won’t-tell.” Felt’s spoon STOPS.
“'There is some very powerful information,’ said one federal official. ‘Especially if it’s known before November 7th.’” (and looks at Felt) Election day--
I know what day it is.
“The FBI Finds”? This is you-- HOLDING on Felt’s calm mask. As he gets up to face everyt this day will bring, picks up his hat, briefcase, heads o
What are they going to do to us? (then smash to--) INT. FELT’S BUICK (STATIONARY A108 In the driveway. Engine running. Felt’s face all wrong. Gripping the wheel. Listening to--

--The White House is vigorously denouncing the story in the Washington Post this morning accusing the administration of engaging in a secret political war. White House press secretary Ron Ziegler is calling the story a “pack of scurrilous lies and innuendo based on faceless cowardly sources inside the Department of Justice.” (and now SMASH to--)
Felt steps out of a crowded elevator, having the breezy workaday exchanges a man who runs the FBI would have.

White House is calling the story a “pack of scurrilous lies and innuendo based on faceless cowardly sources inside the Department of Justice.” As Felt goes deeper into HQ, Felt’s POV (which is our POV literally warps: hyper-aware of Agents carrying copies of Post, reading the Woodward/Bernstein story. He imagines e face, every gesture, every set of eyes accusing him. THEY KNOW IT WAS HIM.  109 110 111 81.
(taking his hat and coat) The Director wants you immediately. SHE KNOWS IT WAS HIM.
INT. GRAY’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - CONTINUOUS 109 Felt enters. The Post sits on Gray’s desk. It’s been obsessively marked with lines and question marks.
(picks up the paper) He’s here, Mark, has to be. There’s a spy in the FBI.
(screaming) “,..FBI agents have established"?? (obviously reading from the story) “One federal investigative official said ... according to FBI reports...” (then) THAT’S US, GODDAMMIT! 111
Felt, Gray and Bates standing at the top of a conference room. They're facing Kunkel, Lano and the 26 Field Agents the Washington Field Office.
With Gray, raking cold condemnation over the men.
(seething) There is information in here that the Bureau only got 72 hours ago! Gentlemen, are you goddamn joking?? (then) Mr. Felt, you had something you wanted to say.  82.
The last few days I’ve heard various people accuse Mr. Lano of leaking to the press.
(reddening) You have got to be kidding me. Murmurs. Eyes turn on Lano.
And that he and certain newspaper reporters have been seen together.
Think I’m gonna be sick. NOW BATES begins what will become a long escalating stare Felt, putting something together.

I wanted to say to you, Mr. Lano, in front of everyone here, that I know these are vicious lies by jealous agents. You’re doing a fine job, and no matter what the Director and I will support you. Felt nods it back to Gray.

I may not be a FBI lifer like some of you. I’m certainly no Mark Felt. Since I arrived here I have put up with paranoia, insubordination, second-guessing. Gentlemen, it’s Come to Jesus time. Whoever the leaker is, whoever is the Judas among you betraying me, the other good men in this room, his family, God, not to mention the Bureau and the legacy of J. Edgar Hoover, step forward. Right here. Right now. STOP. A hugely tense and awkward moment. FELT - outwardly on fire ... But CLOSER: a trace of sweat eyes flicking face to face. Who knows? Which ones know? KUNKEL - staring at his shoes, humiliated. LANO - fuck you. And back to--  112 83. FELT - stronger and safer every second that ticks by. And back to-- BATES - he’s staring at Felt. Doesn’t want to be thinking what he’s thinking. But here he is thinking it. No one’s stepping forward. Gray stalks out. Bates now absolutely can’t take his eyes off Felt. Becaus Bates REALLY KNOWS. The room empties. Lano pulls Bates aside.

(whisper) Hey, Charlie, we got an office pool going across the street on who the leak is. My money's on you. INT. BATES’ OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 112 Bates packing years of memorabilia, files and junk into boxes. Kunkel wanders in.
What’s the body count?
Eight so far. You, me, a few guys on my team.
Angie?
(shakes No) The guy’s a cockroach. He’d survive a nuclear blast.
Where they sending you?
St. Louis. You?
San Francisco.
At least it’s Frisco.  84.
Yeah? Good. (tearing up) Yeah.
How many years you put in here, Charlie?
The whole run. My kids were born here. A long beat, then--
Did you know? (Bates just looks at him) About Felt.
What about him? A long pause.
Do you? Kunkel seems to sag. Implode. Shrink.
I do now.
Some things are bigger than you and me, Bobby. It has to be that way. Kunkel waits, but there’s nothing else to say, so he just leaves.

head_text.subj: NIXON IN BLACK TIE ON TV ADDRESSES A CAMPAIGN DINNER

text: Did I hear right, my friends? Are we not twenty points ahead?! PULL BACK TO REVEAL the TV’s in  113
A cop-and-fireman joint. Felt, Miller and Bates drinking the bar. Miller brings over beers.
I appreciate you taking the time, Mr. Felt. Felt looks at him.
(quietly) Mark--

I always take care of my people, Mr. Bates. In fact, my father always said to me, ‘Mark, whatever we do, we have to make our lives vectors. Lines with force and direction.’ 85. 113 And makes some stabbing motion with his hand. Forward. Fo Bates and Miller exchange a glance. Felt’s drunk as shit.

So he gave me a horse. Yeah, I hadda horse. When I was a boy. My daddy gave it to me to teach me how to protect something, bring it along, be a man about things. A man with vectors. More stabbing. They’re nodding. Pretending to understand.
Catches sick. Bad sick. I got on my knees and prayed to God to save that horse, and to save me. Because everything I was was on the line, Mr. Miller.
I know.
Pride, faith in God, my father’s respect. (beat; then) He put the gun in my hand and said I had to shoot that horse myself. (MORE )

And I looked the horse in the eyes and I shot him looking him straight in the eyes. (to Miller) I destroyed that sick horse the way you have to destroy anything that is sick beyond repair. To rescue it from its agony.
Mark-- (and makes a move to take him away, but--)
And the agony it causes everyone else . Mr. Bates.
Blood never really comes off wood plank, you know. Seeps in like paint. (then) Failed that horse ... Failed my father ... Failed. And so had to destroy.
(TV)
ee
Nixon flashing his Victory V's.
That’s a sad story, Mr. Felt. Felt’s emotional. Drunker than they thought. Vulnerable.
Mr. Felt? Bates is going to do it, ask him straight out. Miller can feel it coming. Felt turns, Huh?
(low) What are you doing, Charlie? (long excruciating beat) Do not--
(his imperiousness returns) What is it, Mr. Bates? Bates can’t do it. Raises a glass:
Here’s to you. Bravo. They toast.

San Francisco, Charlie. Plum assignment. They were going to send you to Omaha. Wanted you to know. I watch out for my men and their families. INT. FELT’S HOME - LATER THAT NIGHT Tick-tock go the clocks. The herds of china elephants kee watch. Efrem Zimbalist Jr. wheels and fires from the wall the den.

Felt’s smoking at his desk, Coltrane playing in the b.g. little unsteady, a little drunk. Lets his eyes close. Slo 114 g 115  116 87. Smoke curling up his face. Deeply listening to the music. saxophone runs and the controlled chaos of the improv. Th gunfire drumming. His eyes open. Vigilant. He takes out of his briefcase tw more ‘return-to-sender’ letters. Pulls the address list o of his wallet. Been refolded and thumbed up a hundred tim now. Felt checks off these last addresses. Flattens the list o the desk. WE MOVE IN ON THE LIST: just one address left: Genesis Commune, Ben Lomand, California. Felt picks up the phone. Dials. And we cut to--
The phone rings. BATES fumbles for the receiver, turns on bed light. His wife wakes up.
Hello? (now intercutting--)
One last thing before you leave us, Mr. Bates.
Of course. Hold on. (and reaches for something to write on)
Genesis Commune. Ben Lomand. California. Bates scratches down the name.
Check it thoroughly.
Do we think the Underground's there?
No muscle, Mr. Bates. Nothing in the files. I want you to handle it personally.  117 118 88.
I don’t understand. What are we looking for?
Joan Felt. My daughter. Long pause.
Is the morning okay? Or right now? Tonight?
Morning’s fine. And Mr. Yes, Mr. Felt? Bates.
You can leave what you find with Mr. Miller.
Mr. Miller. Good night, sir.
Good night. (and hangs up, and--)

Do you have any idea what that would mean?

Treason. For one. Betrayal of everything the FBI stands for. For another. (and then) Everything you stand for. The humming crescendoing. What did he miss? Who overheard him? Now Felt EYES the room for a good place to plant a b
So why would I do it?
I don’t know. I can’t imagine their thinking.
Why don’t they fire me?
They’re terrified of you. You know everything. (--)
To them, the only thing worse than keeping you is firing you. THE HUM DOMINANT NOW. Felt’s pov pinballing around the ro now: Where’s that damn bug?
Dean did say something strange. Apparently they know everything going on inside our shop. They have a “source”.
Inside the FBI?

He said they hear everything. (HOLD, then smash to) Al19 FELT FEELING UNDER THE DESK. Gray’s left the room. F alone. Eyeballing every surface, every corner. MRS. TSCHUDY enters with a stack of folders.
Can I get you an aspirin?  119 90.
Have Mr. Bates sweep our offices for bugs.
Mr. Bates is gone, Mr. Felt.
Have Mr. Miller do it.
We just had your office swept, Mr. Felt.

Do they know?!

Do they know what--? What?? What do you think they know? What is there to know? (explodes at her) Can you for once in your life just shut up, Audrey!! Just shut the hell up! And as Audrey freezes, Felt runs. WE FOLLOW HIM to the ba edging the pool, toward the pitch dark of the woods behin right to the edge of it. Defiance. C'mon! Here I am! ... C’MON!  120 121 91. INT. GRAY’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY 120 Felt and Miller. Felt back to his composed imperious self
I asked Mr. Miller to join us as a witness. (heavy silence; then) This is my fault. It is me. Miller and Gray stare at him, stunned.
(confused) Mark, what are you saying?

Everything that happens inside this building is my responsibility. If there is a rat, if the White House has someone inside the Bureau, I should know. So it’s on me. (and so) I want your permission to do a full internal investigation. I’1l bring down an inspection team from New York. I want everyone who’s been in contact with the Watergate files polygraphed. I’1l run it myself.
(and throws a glance at Miller) They’11 hate you for it.

Everything is on the line. We're running out of time. (and cut to--) ANGIE LANO’S FACE FILLING THE SCREEN, STUCK IN A SNEER. 1 PULL BACK TO REVEAL an interrogation room. Lano’s hooked to a polygraph machine, answering a POLYGRAPHER’S questio
Is an observation room. Felt watches with Miller.
How many is that?  122 92.
Fifteen total. Mr. Lano’s the last.
And we don't have a thing. (troubled) Has the FBI ever done this to its own?

I want Mr. Lano to sign a sworn affidavit that he has not passed information to Woodward or Bernstein or any other reporter. I want everyone in the Washington Field Office to sign one. Miller looks at him.
You're humiliating them. Through the glass Lano is RIPPING off the wires and electrodes. The Polygrapher steps out.
Okay are you ready?
For what?
The polygraph.
Never.
His own orders. No exceptions. Lano has stepped out.
I‘1l tell you one thing. It’1l make all this go down easier for the rest of us. Lano glares. Felt imperious, opaque. A long pause. Felt’s cornered. Nowhere to look. Turns right into it. To Miller
(the bluff) Do it, Mr. Miller. Set it up. INT. FELT’S OFFICE - FBI HO - DAY 122 Felt at his desk.  93.
Mr. Dean at the White House.
(picks up) Mr. Dean.

Pat Gray was quite taken by the way you've taken charge. He said you insisted on having yourself polygraphed but your own men wouldn’t allow it. (then) Lucky for you, I guess. Beat. Then they both laugh.
Nothing like this in the history of the FBI, I understand. They both wait for the other to blink. Felt can wait all
You don’t have it yet.
Progress is slow. Pause. Tense silence.
This must be very uncomfortable for you. (and holding on Felt--)

FOUR MORE YEARS! FOUR MORE It was a great victory, but YEARS the greater the victory, the greater the responsibility, the greater the opportunity! The applause CRESCENDOING as we cut to-- NIXON ON TV SPEECHIFYING THROUGH A CONFETTI RAIN.
...dedicating ourselves to those great goals that I have discussed at such great length throughout this campaign-- (and now)  123
INT. DEN - FELT’S HOME - NIGHT 123 Felt and Audrey watch TV.

(broadcast) With a more than 22% margin of victory, some are referring to this as the greatest victory in American political history. Felt rises, shuts it off. He leaves the room. We follow him through the house room room. To the phone. He picks it up but doesn’t dial. He j listens a long beat. Puts it down. Crosses to the window peers out. STREET - an FBI car sits out front. Two Agents watching t house. We HOLD on this, suddenly not knowing - as Felt suddenly doesn’t know - who those agents really are. The phone RINGS.
(picks up; into phone) Hello? (silence) Hello? (nothing) Hello? O.S. a door slams. Audrey has gone upstairs. Felt is star at the phone.

(into phone) Is someone there? Now we HEAR WHAT HE HEARS: (OVER) A PATTERN OF CLICKS AND HISSES. Felt hangs up. TAP TAP. Felt whirls. Jumpy. It's a tree. Scraping the glass. Nothing. Back to the window, peers through the curtains. The street is empty.  124 125 95. FADE TO BLACK.
124 Felt’s Buick joins the traffic past the Capitol, whirlpoo past the Lincoln Memorial. The car STOPS past a bus stop along the Potomac. Felt par exits, and--
Felt sits beside a MAN in a trench and hat.
The knives are out.
More than you know.
Am I safe?
No one is. You’re being watched. The White House is going to sanitize the entire town. (then) The Director of Central Intelligence will be gone by morning.
Why.
Apparently, he couldn’t smoke you out fast enough. (Felt looks at him, but says nothing) The source. Of those stories. After a pause.
Where does the CIA stand? 125  126 96.
The CIA is building a wall. We’1l stay out of your way, but if we are forced to protect ourselves we will. (then) The FBI will never reach the CIA on this.
And the White House?
The CIA’s position is, Presidents come and go. The CIA stays. The FBI stays. We are the constants. Felt up, about to walk away.
Almost forgot. Time Magazine's Person of the Year is going to be Richard Nixon. Thought you’d like to know. (--)
Happy Holidays.

UNDER Lawrence Welk’s Christmas Carol schmaltz: a Norman Rockwellian gingerbread happiness. A dozen stockings a- hanging. Crackling fire in the hearth. A Christmas tree afloat on a sea of unwrapped toys. PAN ACROSS the table: Felt and Audrey, Ed and Pat Miller. Miller’s THREE YOUNG CHILDREN. All before their perfect, shiny Christmas dinner. Felt, the patriarch, carves the perfect turkey. Now Felt is playing with Miller’s littlest girl. On his b giving her a plane ride. The girl screeching with delight AUDREY standing in the kitchen doorway, watching. Drinkin
Mark! (lost in the laughter) Do you do that on purpose?
What? C’mon, we’re just having fun. Audrey starts to cry. Pat Miller goes to Audrey.  97.
Honey. What are we doing wrong?
He’s always playing his games.
What games, honey?
He knows-- (and now Ed Miller) You know.
Honey we all care so much.
You blame me, all of you! He does! (Felt; not explodes) What do you all want from me! To laugh and sing? !
Do you think you’re the only one in pain?! Can’t you see anything except how it affects you?!

No! I can’t! It’s just maybe I’ma little more honest about it-- (an awkward quiet, and Pat pulls her into the foyer, the two women) Don’t you dare say anything until you know what it’s like to come home and one of those children is just gone. Because it’1ll happen to you, too--!
Pat, stung, leans in anyway. Eyes moist. Stoic.

It’s easy to be great when they’re babies, isn’t it. Then they become people, and you have to deal with them. Just like everyone else. (and as she goes out--) 127 INT. JOAN’S ROOM - FELT HOME - NIGHT 127
Felt stands in the middle of the room. The room is EMPTY, CLEANED OUT, all signs of human life ERASED. HOLD ... The  128 129 130 131 132
128 THE WATERGATE BURGLARS filing into a Washington DC courtr taking the oath...
As the trial of the five men accused of breaking into the Watergate Hotel continues, alleged ringleader G. Gordon Liddy pled guilty to six felony counts. HOWARD HUNT giving a press conference...
No higher-ups were involved in the break-in. THE BURGLARS now standing at a news conference podium.
Claiming no connection whatsoever to the White House, the Watergate burglars changed their minds and pled guilty to all eight counts...
A limo idles at the curb, in a swirl of snow. The door to Felt’s home opens. Felt crosses shrugging on a coat, and-
Felt slides in next to Gray.

The President told me the unthinkable has happened: he actually misses Hoover. Hoover would have gotten the dogs off him, he said. He’d have everyone scared to death. Felt staring out the window. Into a fresh snowfall.
The White House is going to make me Director permanently.
Congratulations. 129 130 131 132  133 134 99.
Bill Sullivan will be my Number Two. (and waits for Felt’s reaction) That sits there. Long enough for the ramifications to str both men. Felt doesn’t so much as blink. Then--

You know what the President said to me today? He said, ‘The Germans had the right idea during World War II. If they went through a town and one of their soldiers got hit by a sniper, they'd line up the whole goddamn town and kill everyone’. He said it’s time to clean out the FBI.
You know what that will mean for me.
Remember, they’re afraid of you. The President said you know everything there is to know in the FBI. (--)
Mark. If you did know something, you could come to me. We’d be able to work it out together. We could do something about it. Nothing. Pause. Felt starts to get out--
I can’t protect you any more. Just give them what they want. The traitor’s head on a platter. (and then we find--)

Felt watches the limo’s taillights recede, then to-- INT. JOAN’S ROOM - FELT HOME 134 Felt entering. Audrey close behind. Looking for a place t alone. Enters here. The one room he knows Audrey won’t en Closing the door on her.  135
Mark? (stares at the wood, and now INTERCUT) FELT ON THE OTHER SIDE. Their foreheads connected by wood
I know you did it to save us from those lunatics. Felt squeezes his eyes. She feels him there, reached for where his head would be. Then turns. Back against the doo Guarding him. Then--
Felt on his way up alone. Doors open. A half-dozen agents step on. Sullivan among them.
Nice to see you.
What brings you back?
Two words. Re-venge. Sullivan pushes out. The doors close. And we find Felt in

INT. HOOVER’S OFFICE - FBI HQ - DAY A136 His and our first time in since he claimed the throne as Now, it is lost. As he stands there before all he has fai we cut to-- Carol waiting for him outside. Until she can’t wait any m
Mr. Felt. Mr. Miller is on the phone. (now cut to--) INT. /EXT. FELT’S CAR/FBI GARAGE - THAT DAY 136
Felt emerges from the elevator, crossing toward his parke car. Loitering around is Miller and an UNDERCOVER AGENT, plainclothes in his 20's.
Felt passes them without so much as a nod, simply gets in car, and waits. Miller nods at the agent. They both get i with Felt. Miller up front, the agent behind.
This is Special Agent Clarke-- I don’t want to know his name.
Tell him what you told Mr. Bates and me. Agent nervous. Felt’s imperious eyes in the rear view mir study him.  101.
I don’t think you have anything to worry about, Mr. Felt.
You don’t think?
Specific.
The commune where the subject, Joan Felt, is--
Do not say her name--
Copy. Where the target is. Definitely some people of interest in there. Maybe some Weather Underground--
But the -- target? Felt’s eyes. Desperate now, almost pleading:

If you ask me, just someone’s kid looking for a way home. (and as we PUSH IN on Felt) To a stranger he gives nothing. But in TIGHTER: his eyes moisten. To us, he’s holding back a flood of relief and agony. As Felt nods--

We never spoke. No paper. You don’t know anything. Get out now. (and as the Agent goes, withdraws into the shadow of the garage) Felt and Miller sit in a long silence. Both men looking ahead. Until Felt, barely a whisper--
Thank you. Miller pats Felt’s hand on the wheel. Holds a beat. The t men. The two fathers. Then leaves him.  137 102.

Felt waits in a booth. The booth we saw him staring into earlier. A violent storm rattles the window. Eyes SCANNING every face. Everyone a suspect. HIS POV lan on hands, expressions, mouths. Eyes seem to come back to His steely glare chases them away. In slides Smith. Shaking the wet off.
Bill Sullivan is picking out colors for his new office. He’s going to turn the FBI into the KGB.
So it’s over. (waitress wanders by)
Bring coffee (then, to Smith) Get out your notebook. (then) May 1969. And February 1971--
Mark. (stopping him - yes?) Are you sure about this? (he’s very fucking sure of this, because--)
Between those dates White House employees were wiretapped, many of them aides to the Secretary of State. And five reporters. Including the New York Times.
You're kidding. (but Felt’s not kidding)
Some of the names of the targets came down from Henry Kissinger. Pause. Smith looks at him.
This is hard for you.  103.
What part?
All this truth. Truth is hard for you. (but now that he’s started Felt wants to just keep going)

The targets went from Kissinger to the FBI. And the FBI illegally, unconstitutionally, and reprehensibly bugged and taped and secretly photographed and memorialized every move those people made. Them and their wives and their mistresses and homosexual lovers.
Who did the wiretaps, Mark?
Bill Sullivan. (which now makes perfect fucking sense) It became a rogue FBI operation. Sullivan drove it. Sullivan and the White House. By themselves.
What about you? (what about me?) What did you know?
About everything else I knew every sordid little detail. But not this. They knew they couldn’t tell me about this.
They couldn’t count on you.

This is when the darkness started to creep in. This is when the rot started to happen. (and a long pause now, the Big Truth coming) The White House is packing all its crimes in separate little boxes ... (MORE )

Watergate, the spying, the ugliness, the rot. Each thing in a different box so no one can put it together, so no one sees it’s all connected ... and no one will care. But it’s all the same big thing. Smith stares. Humbled by all this truth himself now, so--
Watergate is just the gateway. Smith puts down a fork. Or a cup.

Do you know physics, Sandy? If you tap repeatedly on the post of a building, and the beating is relentless, it creates a rhythm, a resonance- (Felt starts to tap the table, slowly, repeatedly «+. tap ... tap ... tap) If you do that long enough, and steadily enough, it will feed-back, the frequencies will align ... the molecules will scramble ... and the whole thing - the whole building - will come apart from the inside and collapse in on itself. And all come tumbling down. (beat) The molecules are beginning to scramble. The FBI is coming apart. You know where that takes us? You want a country this big, this angry, this confused, without a police department? (--)
Sometimes we have to betray the thing we love, to save the thing we love. Which triggers a momentary collapse in Felt. A slow eye- blink. He pats his own head. Then as quickly, embarrassed
This - what you’re doing - will bring down the whole house of cards. The President’s surveillance mania. (--)
But then you already knew that.  138 139 105.
(tired) The White House is a syndicate, Sandy. It’s a criminal organization. (--)
Can you get out the story before Gray’s confirmation hearing?
One week. (and Felt gets up, and--)
Felt and Gray in back. Along with two of Gray’s flacks. G pouring over a legal pad of notes. Felt stares out the window as the Capitol comes into view
Any last-minute advice?

We've gone over everything. They’11l go easy; you’re the President's man. GRAY’S FLACK What about this? And pulls out the Smith TIME Magazine story. WE PUSH IN o the lead header: “Secret Wiretapping by the FBI”.
I don’t know what my position should be.
It was before your time. Tell the truth. No one can argue with the truth.

Gray is perspiring. It’s going badly. He’s like a boxer i the 8th round taking a serious beating.  106. Arrayed before him, seven U.S. SENATORS, a dozen PHOTOGRAPHERS, 100 SPECTATORS at his back. CAMERA FINDS F in the gallery.

(irate; a Woodward/Wash Post clipping in his hands ) And what about the assertion in this article that a White House aide slipped Donald Segretti, a target of the Bureau’s Watergate investigation, copies of what the FBI had?
(unsteady ) Uh, we didn’t look into that.
Why on earth not?
I’1l have to look into that.
Did you know the White House had your confidential files?
Gray looks to Felt. Felt glances away
I did, yes, Senator. (and pauses, unfocused; desperately wanting to please) Um, let me tell you how it might have happened.
Please do. (and as we continue, we quickly see--)
Gray and Dean sitting side by side on a bench. Gray carri briefcase, Dean a big envelope. As we’re hearing--  107.

White House counsel John Dean told me the White House wanted everything the FBI had on Watergate. To help with its own investigation. (should stop talking, but) It was the President’s wish. So Mr. Dean took all those FBI files Gray puts the briefcase on the ground. Dean opens. Looks through the contents, closes it again. Now back to
Close on FELT as--
I’m confused. How did Mr. Dean, a potential target of the investigation, come to possess FBI files about that investigation?
Because I gave them to him. Something big is happening. The room can feel it.
(grave) How many Bureau reports are we talking about? How many reports did you give Mr. Dean?
I believe it was eighty-two.
As Acting Director of the FBI, why on earth would you do that?
Because I was told to.
By who?
The President. That's it. The room ERUPTS. But we’re holding on Felt.  141 108.
So, if I have this right, Mr. Dean purposely mis-led the FBI. Lied to them?
(before he thinks--) I would have to conclude that probably is correct, yes sir. The room is electric. As we start to intercut with--
A dozen stockings dangle over a fireplace. Gray - in card with reindeers - approaching with an armful of wrapping paper. Tosses it all onto the fire, now contemplating the flames, as we go back to--
I do understand, though, that the materials you’re talking about were kept in a safe in the White House.
And how would you know that?

I know because Mr. Dean gave those and other files to me. (and now back to--) THE CABIN. Where Gray is left standing at the fire cradli small stack of files stamped “TOP SECRET. EYES ONLY.” And starts to read. Then wishes he hadn't. And now simply throws all that into the flames, and now s back to--

He told me they should never see the light of day. He told me to ‘deep six’ the files. To destroy them. (and then) I burned them at my vacation home.  142 143 There it is. Like a bomb going off, the room explodes. Fe who set this up all along - is the one still point in the room. EXT. WASHINGTON D.C. - MORNING - FELT’S BUICK Crossing the Potomac.
As we follow it past the Capitol, the White House, and in the FBI HQ--

Today, in one of the most difficult decisions of my presidency, I accepted the resignations of two of my closest associates in the White House -- John Ehrlichman, Bob Haldeman -- two of the finest public servants it has been my privilege to know. The counsel to the president, John Dean, has also resigned.
Felt approaches the elevator doors. WE HEAR footsteps.

So the President asks me what he should do-- (Felt slows, feels Sullivan behind him) And I tell him to get rid of everyone. In the interests of the nation. I didn't mean me, of course. Felt has reached the elevator. He presses the button. SULLIVAN (CONT’D) You don't have many friends left, you know. A bunch of your FBI pals told me I should cut your nuts off. (--)
They gonna let you keep your badge? (Felt turns now, imperious) You got a lotta people Washington worried. They think you're going to come out and unwrap everything. (MORE )
142 143  144 110. SULLIVAN (CONT’D) Everything from all the years. Everything we [you and I] know. (as Felt steps into the elevator)
Is that what you want to know, Bill? This your last little errand? To help everyone sleep at night?

Just saying. You open those scabs, there’s a lot of things underneath. Doors finally open. And as Felt steps in, and doors close SULLIVAN (CONT’D) Just remember. No one likes informers. They only remember you as a rat. Even if you were their rat.

Felt enters. Puts down his briefcase. Hangs up his hat an coat. Crosses to Audrey at the table. A day like any othe Felt sits in front of a tall Manhattan. Pulls at the drin He takes out his list of California commune addresses now spreads it out on the table between them. That one addres circled now: “Genesis Commune, Ben Lomand."
I found her. (she goes still; a long beat; disbelief--)
You found her. Alive? Is she in trouble? Felt eyes moisten, grateful. He shakes his head, No.
How long have you known?
A week.
A week? Mark?? You can play games with all of them-- (MORE )
(points outside) But-- (she starts to cry) I’m her mother.
It wasn’t safe.
For who? Beat. Audrey’s silent.
Let’s just go get our baby.
Empty hills, wild flowers, azure sky. lll. 145 TWO YOUNG BEAUTIFUL WOMEN sit in a field, completely nake nursing INFANTS, sharing a joint. We know one from

Just promise me you’1l remember. No matter what: our bodies are beautiful. (and) And don’t fall in love with him. All my friends fall in love with him. Joan defiant. They half-dress. Car stops. Felt and out. He in his FBI suit. She with white gloves and pill b hat. Audrey get  112.

That’s your dad?? He’s gorgeous! Felt can’t get to Joan fast enough. Walking first. Then h runs. And without a word or permission he just wraps her the baby in his arms, just like that. And starts to cry. by the sheer force of his love Joan relents and collapses into him, just like that. Audrey holds onto the car door, paralyzed. WIDE & LONG - THREE HIPPIE MEN jogging out from the commu

Mark?
This is your grandson. Felt presses the baby to Audrey’s breast, takes one of he arms and wraps it around the child.
Audrey, this is Ludi.
You sent the FBI after me? (Felt, smiling, shakes, No) Then how did you find me? And Felt takes out one of the envelopes he’s been address
One didn’t come back. Felt opens his arms and pulls both his women into him. Th two women collapsing against each other.
Whatever happened, whatever I did, whatever we did - or didn’t do - I’m sorry - we’re sorry. We need you. Your mother and I need you now.  146 113.

Felt strolling, contemplative, alone, among the shelters playing kids. Jacket over his shoulder. Shoulder holster visible but empty. While-- Audrey on a bench. Holding Ludi. With her gloves and pill hat. Joan beside her. She’s a little drunk. Joan knows. Joan looks at her a lit sadly, then at Felt--
I had this feeling when I was little, that I couldn’t see into his eyes. That he didn’t approve of me. He was always holding me up to some impossible standard.
That was me. (--)

When you were sick, and you were little, it was your father who climbed into bed with you. In his shoes. His holster. His suit. He’d sit with you for hours and rock you til you fell asleep again. Joan looks at Felt. As if to ask, what did you do?
I used to dress you up. Remember how you used to come downstairs and show off your new clothes? (Felt--) He adored you. He thought you could be the first female President-- (--)
I wanted you to be [like me][a movie star]. They both watch Felt stroll. Joan touches her mother’s kn Connection. And pity.
He talks to me. You know how he is. I’m the only one he can really talk to. (and then--)  147 148 114.

Joan gets out of a VW van with DOUGLAS GILLIES: pony tail beard. 27 but looks 18. Joan leads him toward a converted chicken coop, long and low. Stops at the door. Gillies hesitates, then-- INT. JOAN’S BUNK - GENESIS COMMUNE - SAME 148
Joan and Gillies enter to find Felt sitting in the miniat room, an empty chair across from him.
Daddy, this is my friend. He’s a lawyer.
Douglas Gillies. (and as Felt takes him in)
When did you graduate from law school?

Ten months ago. Felt sighs, stands - has to stoop - shakes Gillies’ hand. GILLIES (CONT’D) Look, I didn’t want to come. You stand for everything I despise. I came because I admire your daughter, and she asked me. (and Felt, as if he simply chose not to hear that, says--)

Have a seat. (when he’s down) I need to consult an attorney. (and hands him a dollar) I am now protected by attorney- client privilege. Whatever I say to you, you can never tell a living soul without my permission.
I know that. But why me? Felt looks at Gillies. His strong, almost Job-like presen Felt shifts in his chair, more and more uncomfortable.  115.

Because you are now - as my lawyer - the only person in America I can trust. (and doesn’t quite know how to react to that strange and terrible irony) I’ve been in the FBI Longer than you've been alive. I live according to a code. There are things an FBI man does and doesn’t do. It’s black and white. (rambling) But there’s loyalty. And then there’s duty. There are things bigger than ourselves. Can you understand that?
Yes.
I’ve done something - things - that cannot be undone. But I want to know what I’ve done. (and looks up at him) Am I the man I think I am? Pause. Gillies takes in this man in obvious pain.
You want to know about your soul. (--)
You want to know who is going to forgive you. Felt looks through the slats in the barn wall. Catches fragments of Audrey quietly coming close, trying to hear.
(realizing) I don’t need a lawyer. I need a priest. And now we begin to HEAR in PRE-LAP:
I have never been a quitter. To leave office before my term is completed is abhorrent to every instinct in my body. (and cut to)  149 150 116.
Felt in the doorway of Joan’s coop, watching Gillies’ van disappear over the hills. His expression relaxed, unburde

But as President, I must put the interest of America first. (continuing over) Joan stepping into Felt, and Felt puts his arm around her NIXON (OVER) (CONT’D) Therefore, I shall resign the Presidency effective at noon tomorrow. (continuing as we go to--)
Felt’s retirement party, subdued and sparsely attended.

Vice President Ford will be sworn in as President at that hour in this office. (continuing over--) Felt shaking lots of hands, smiling with grace. No one ma eye contact. Now cut to- Audrey sits in the corner by herself. Then-- NIXON (OVER) (CONT’D) But as President, I must put the interest of America first. Felt is presented with a plaque, a watch.
